discussion.content: Answer is B. P2V - going from physical servers in Company B's datacenter into virtual private cloud of Company A
The answer is B - P2V. It doesn't say it can't be virtualized, just say it cannot be removed from the current datacenter. P2V would convert it without needing to remove it from the datacenter.
This is one I'd like to know who entered the answer. C is literally the opposite of what you need to do. Answer is B.

from the question we know it must to be P2X. the question is X=P or X=V.
1,legacy server --> you can not buy same hardware for P2P (I don't think the word legacy here indicate it can not be virtualized)
2,the server can not removed from current datacenter -->can not use lift&shift P2P
So X=VB is the right answer
no matter what , it can't be V2X

vague question but I think you can move the application from physical to virtual and not have to worry about the data center. maybe a lift and shift migration if the application happens to be outdated.

going with B.
I think either C or D. some legacy stuff cant be virtualized but is the equipment in B's data center virtualized or is it on physical servers there too?
Shouldn't it be P2V? since they are moving from Legacy server to Private cloud (or virtualized host)? please help to figure this out :)

comments.content: "Some legacy hardware simply can't be emulated in a virtual infrastructure. Performing a P2V migration with a DOS-based accounting package running on 16-bit hardware, for instance, isn't an option because none of the major virtualization platforms support 16-bit guest OSes." Ref:https://searchservervirtualization.techtarget.com/definition/physical-to-virtual

questions.question_text: Company A just acquired Company B and needs to migrate critical applications to Company A's private cloud infrastructure. Company B's applications are running on legacy servers and cannot be removed from the current datacenter where they reside. Which of the following migration strategies should the cloud administrator use?

Ann, the lead product developer for a company, just hired three new developers. Ann asked the cloud administrator to give these developers access to the fileshares in the public cloud environment. Which of the following is the BEST approach for the cloud administrator to take?

choices.D: Create a new role to access the fileshares and assign the three new developers.
choices.C: Copy the fileshares to each new developer's laptop.
choices.B: Distribute the credentials of Ann's shared account to the three new developers.
choices.A: Clone Ann's account to create three new developer accounts.

comments.content: wtf, she could have other role and other privileges, for this reason she can ask for access to the new developers

questions.question_text: A company hosts its server in a public IaaS cloud. The company's management decides to migrate the servers to a different geographical region that is closer to the user base. A cloud administrator creates a new environment in that geographical region. Which of the following is the BEST way to migrate the VM from the original geographic region to the new region?

discussion.content:
B. has to be the best answer.
Using FTP isnt a secure method and I wouldn't go with D since you may have to change the network and security group setting.
I see why the answer is D, FTP is used and they did not use SFTP or FTPS. It's a tricky question

choices.B: 1. Create a VM image. 2. Export the VM image to the new region using vendor's tools. 3. Deploy a new VM based on the created image.
choices.A: 1. Create a full backup of the VM. 2. Copy the backup files into the new region using FTP. 3. Restore the VM from the backup files.
choices.C: 1. Create a VM clone. 2. Copy the clone into the new region using FTP. 3. Apply the network and security groups from the new region to the cloned VM and start it.
choices.D: 1. Create a new VM in the new region. 2. Restore a full-system backup from the original VM. 3. Apply the network and security groups from the original region to the new VM.

discussion.content:
Answer is C

Non-Discretionary Access Control
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) defines how information is accessed on a system based on the role of the subject. A role could be a nurse, a backup administrator, a help desk technician, etc. Subjects are grouped into roles and each defined role has access permissions based upon the role, not the individual.

Discretionary Access Controls (DAC)
Discretionary Access Control (DAC) gives subjects full control of objects they have created or been given access to, including sharing the objects with other subjects. Subjects are empowered and control their data. Standard UNIX and Windows operating systems use DAC for file systems: subjects can grant other subjects access to their files, change their attributes, alter them, or delete them.
If a subject makes a mistake, such as attaching the wrong file to an email sent to a public mailing list, loss of confidentiality can result. Mistakes and malicious acts can also lead to a loss of integrity or availability of data.

Selected Answer: C
Agree with neil and night, answer should be C

comments.content: No NDAC is another term for object based access control which cloud based

discussion.content:
The answer is C 
as neil001 said Non-discretionary is another term from RBAC
